Activities are started automatically now. There are cases when user intervention is required, such as deploying services to production environment. I suppose it would be better to let the users to actually start the activity.

I'm not sure at the moment.

comments.body:
You shall be able to do this via signals. In your workflow, you can wait on a signal channel. When your user is ready to start the next activity, you can send signal to the target workflow (via your web portal when user click on some button that calls temporal API to send signal or directly using tctl). Upon receiving the signal, your workflow could start activity.
See more: https://docs.temporal.io/docs/node/signals/#when-to-use-signals

@yiminc Many thanks for your reply.
If this kind of workflows can keep running for a very long time (hours even days), and there will be a lot of them, will they eat up the resources of our whole system? Or are they very lightweight? I think this question applies to workflows in https://github.com/temporalio/temporal/issues/1882 as well.

And what will happen if I restart the temporal server. Will the workflows still be there and wait on the signal channel ?

I'm sorry for my ignorance of the implementation of Temporal.

@philosophicus , workflow is lightweight entity, temporal is designed to handle very large number of workflows. 
Temporal handles failure cases including client side worker restart and temporal server restart. All of those are handled in a transparent way that your code won't event notice.

@yiminc That's very reassuring. Thanks a lot. Do you mind telling me something about the reason why workflows are lightweight entities? Or maybe could you guide me to the code where I should start to explore to learn about the reason myself?

When workflow is in idle mode (sleep for long time, or waiting for signals for long time), it does not consume any resource on server. On client worker side, idle workflow is sitting in a sticky cache (LRU) doing nothing, it won't consume CPU, but it does consume some memory. However, it would be evicted if other workflows take up the slots in the LRU cache. So in general, idle workflow does not consume much. For busy workflow, it consume resource as any other code you would write.
